pr_title: [HUDI-1083] Optimization in determining insert bucket location for a given key

timeline.message: [HUDI-1083] Minor optimization in determining insert bucket location for a given key
[HUDI-1083] Optimization in determining insert bucket location for a given key
[HUDI-1083] Optimization in determining insert bucket location for a given key
[HUDI-1083] Optimization in determining insert bucket location for a given key

timeline.bodyText:
Somehow I don't feel comfortable adding cumulative weights to InsertBucket class. Each Insert bucket doesn't have anything to do with strict ordering wrt other buckets. UpsertPartitioner has some ordering for its own purpose.
Can we try something like this.
partitionPathToInsertBucketInfo : Map<String, List/Array of Pair of <Insert Bucket number, cumulative weight> >
InsertBucketMap: Map of insert bucket number to InsertBucket object.
getPartition(key)
will first look at partitionPathToInsertBucketInfo to fetch list of cumulative weights of all insert buckets along with insert bucket nos. Once we found the target bucket number, we can look into other map.
Or you can store InsertBucket itself in the value of partitionPathToInsertBucketInfo to avoid another look up. Tuple3<cumulativeWeight, InsetBucket>
timeline.author: nsivabalan
nsivabalan

timeline.bodyText: sorry why do we need this? if not found, why not return the first bucket ?
timeline.author: nsivabalan

replies.bodyText: also, ideally we should not hit this scenario only. If our bin packing is good, cumulative weight of last entry should be 1.0.
replies.author: nsivabalan

replies.bodyText:
sorry why do we need this? if not found, why not return the first bucket ?

Collections.binarySearch() will return the index of the search key, if it is contained in the list;   otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1).  The insertion point is defined as the point at which the key would be inserted into the list: the index of the first element greater than the key, or list.size() if all  elements in the list are less than the specified key.
replies.author: shenh062326

replies.bodyText: gotcha. can we add braces. ((-1*index) -1) in both if condition and in the return statement
replies.author: nsivabalan

replies.bodyText: Sure, I will fix the comments.
replies.author: shenh062326

you don't need to declare. We could directly call.
int index = Collections.binarySearch(targetBuckets, new InsertBucket2CumulativeWeight(new InsertBucket(), r));

replies.author: shenh062326

timeline.bodyText: sorry, probably I mis guided you. (should not happen) but incase the last buckets cumulative weight is not 1.0, there are chances that index value could be equal to size of collection when entry searched for is greater than all entries. Can we accommodate that as well.
timeline.author: nsivabalan

replies.bodyText:
The last buckets cumulative weight should be 1, and the search entry should not greater than the last entry.
Even if the search entry greater than all entries, it will return the last bucketNumber.
replies.author: shenh062326

replies.bodyText:
From docs, I see that list.size() will be returned.
the index of the first element greater than the key, or list.size() if all elements in the list are less than the specified key.

which means, it could throw ArrayIndexOutOfBounds. Let me know if I am missing something.
replies.author: nsivabalan
shenh062326

replies.bodyText: it is fine. Would you mind adding assertions for all buckets.
replies.author: nsivabalan

replies.bodyText: Sure, I will add for all buckets.

timeline.bodyText: lets avoid doing one at a time w/ hardcoded expected values. I mean, we should try to do in a loop. Can we build a map of <index -> ExpectedValue>. ExpectedValue should contain bucketNo, bucketType, weight, cumulativeWeight. Once we have this, these 20 lines of assertions will be folded to just 4 to 5 lines.

timeline.bodyText: same as above. Can we try to fold this up in a loop.
